title: Hisashi Kato
text:
is a former <a href="Japan">Japan</a>ese <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player and manager. He played for <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a>.
Club career.
Kato was born in <a href="Rifu">Rifu</a>, <a href="Miyagi%20Prefecture">Miyagi</a> on April 24, 1956. After graduating from <a href="Waseda%20University">Waseda University</a>, after a year's blank, he joined <a href="Tokyo%20Verdy">Yomiuri</a> (later "Verdy Kawasaki") in 1980. The club won the champions in <a href="Japan%20Soccer%20League">Japan Soccer League</a> 5 times, <a href="JSL%20Cup">JSL Cup</a> 2 times and <a href="Emperor%27s%20Cup">Emperor's Cup</a> 3 times. This was golden era in club history. In 1992, Japan Soccer League was folded and founded new league <a href="J1%20League">J1 League</a>. The club won <a href="1992%20J.League%20Cup">1992 J.League Cup</a>. J1 League <a href="1993%20J.League">first season</a> in 1993, although he played in opening match, he lost opportunity to play after that. So, he moved to <a href="Shimizu%20S-Pulse">Shimizu S-Pulse</a> in July. In July 1994, he returned to Verdy Kawasaki. The club won <a href="1994%20J.League">J1 League</a> and retired end of 1994 season. He was 38 years old. He played 243 games and scored 11 goals in the league. He was selected Best Eleven 9 times.
National team career.
On November 19, 1978, when Kato was a <a href="Waseda%20University">Waseda University</a> student, he debuted for <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a> against <a href="Soviet%20Union%20national%20football%20team">Soviet Union</a>. He played at <a href="Football%20at%20the%201978%20Asian%20Games">1978</a> and <a href="Football%20at%20the%201982%20Asian%20Games">1982 Asian Games</a>. From 1984, he served as captain and played at <a href="Football%20at%20the%201984%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20qualification">1984 Summer Olympics qualification</a>, <a href="1986%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28AFC%29">1986 World Cup qualification</a>, <a href="Football%20at%20the%201986%20Asian%20Games">1986 Asian Games</a> and <a href="Football%20at%20the%201988%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20qualification">1988 Summer Olympics qualification</a>. At 1988 Olympics qualification in 1987, Japan failed to qualify for <a href="Football%20at%20the%201988%20Summer%20Olympics">1988 Summer Olympics</a> and he retired from national team. He played 61 games and scored 6 goals for Japan until 1987.
Coaching career.
After retirement, Kato became a manager for <a href="Tokyo%20Verdy">Verdy Kawasaki</a> in 1997. But he resigned in July. In 2000, he signed with <a href="J2%20League">J2 League</a> club <a href="Shonan%20Bellmare">Shonan Bellmare</a>. However the club finished 8th place, he was sacked end of 2000 season. In 2007, he signed with J2 club <a href="Kyoto%20Sanga%20FC">Kyoto Sanga FC</a> and became a general manager. However he sacked manager <a href="Naohiko%20Minobe">Naohiko Minobe</a> and Kato became new manager in October. He led the club to won 3rd place in 2007 and promoted to <a href="J1%20League">J1 League</a>. In July 2010, he was sacked.
In 2018, Kato was selected <a href="Japan%20Football%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Japan Football Hall of Fame</a>.
